channel.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
channel.description:
Hey there.
Whats a good first programming language to learn? I have made a few moparscape servers,(Well Edited :P) and i am really into programming. What i want to know is are some programming languages alot easier than others? I have a bit of experience in java. I know all about varibles and that sort of stuff and can create a few simple programms. The best besing a Temprature converter!!
So, should i stick with learning java or should i switch to a easier option. I'm strugling with OOP (Object orintated programing) at the moment :/
Thanks if you can help -FaTCaT-

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @JukuG JukuG
item.description:
@JukuG wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:24, topic:171949”]Not sure I’d agree. For example, personally, I love the C++ syntax (although not the silly idiosyncrasies), whereas some people hate it. I prefer Python’s syntax to Ruby’s, where most people would say I’m insane. People have their own preferences.

It’s universally accepted that Pascal is evil though, that just goes without saying.[/quote]
I also like the C++ syntax, I’m currently learning that as well. C++ is a lot easier then Java imo.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Not sure I’d agree. For example, personally, I love the C++ syntax (although not the silly idiosyncrasies), whereas some people hate it. I prefer Python’s syntax to Ruby’s, where most people would say I’m insane. People have their own preferences.

It’s universally accepted that Pascal is evil though, that just goes without saying.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @JukuG JukuG
item.description:
@JukuG wrote:

I recommend ruby I’m also starting that and it’s quite easy going.

Freddy1990:

After replying many times to this question I’ve come to realize that there’s no good answer to it. Some people will be more confortable with certain languages than others, it’s a matter of personal flavor…

And by taste you mean exactly what? There is no programming language “taste” you just simply dive from one to the other until you finally run into a language that is easier then the others. And that’s mainly do to the fact that due to all the delving in different languages, you finally start memorizing syntax and so forth, making the language you “feel” comfortable with easier. Thus “taste” does not exist.

Damn, that took a while to come up with

Read full topic

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @Spikey_Hair Spikey Hair
item.description:
@Spikey_Hair wrote:

Lin:

Well in my opinion, the easiest programming languages are Visual Basic (.NET is harder than regular VB) and C#, they both use mainly English. VB is nicknamed the English programming language. But you’ll find out it’s slightly different than other programming languages.

Lol, visual Basic almost made me laugh and cry. Programming should not be that easy… An idiot could program in VB. Not to mention that half of VB is done for you when your doing the layout lol.

Read full topic

@Freddy1990 wrote:

After replying many times to this question I’ve come to realize that there’s no good answer to it. Some people will be more confortable with certain languages than others, it’s a matter of personal flavor…

@Lin wrote:

Well in my opinion, the easiest programming languages are Visual Basic (.NET is harder than regular VB) and C#, they both use mainly English. VB is nicknamed the English programming language. But you’ll find out it’s slightly different than other programming languages.

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @Spikey_Hair Spikey Hair
item.description:
@Spikey_Hair wrote:

Yz85Racer:

Java.

Yea, I started with java, read some books, and it kinda just came to me. It is preety easy and straight forward. Depends on what you wana do though. If you wana do Web stuff, start with HTML of PHP. Personally, HTML is a bit easier than PHP but deffinately not as powerful.

.[quote=“voiD dev, post:17, topic:171949”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=232058.msg1989228#msg1989228 date=1200004179]

Spend a day at barnes and nobles, get something to drink, eat, sit down, and learn Java or other language. So you don’t have to buy the book, but you’re better off buying it. If you don’t have a Barnes and Nobles just do it at local book store. Thats what I do.
[/quote]Well, it’d be good to bring a laptop or something with you It’s hard to do examples without a computer!

Get anything by Herbert Schildt, mainly Java: The Complete Reference, and Java: A Beginner’s Guide.

His C++ books are good at explaining yet they contain errors in the source code according to the many development communities.[/quote]

Yea, I like his stuff. It works well. I always barrow the Java The Complete Reference Seventh Eddition from my library. Works like a charm and helps me whenever I get stuck on something. It’s quite thick though. It’s exactly 1024 pages from front to back, but that is including the extra stuff in the back and the table of contents. But good luck and have fun :P. I know I did

Read full topic

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Javascript dosen’t even exist.

I would have to strongly recommend against Java, and put in another vote for Python or Ruby.

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Considering you know a bit of Java, I’d say move away from p-servers and get a good book or something.

However, I would suggest staying away from vb(visual basics) and any scripting language, since a scripting language may teach you the syntax, but that is it, your better off diving into the deep end.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @KryptoN KryptoN_
item.description:
@KryptoN wrote:

Heh, yea I’d also have to say Python.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @ripzone Triton
item.description:
@ripzone wrote:

Almost any language would be good, but you might want to stay away from C / C++ (I started with C and if you don’t have any help it is a pain).

My suggestion would be Python. It makes you properly indent your code, which is always a good thing for a beginner, it has support for procedural and object-oriented programming paradigms, has a nice library and community around it.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @fellixombc fellixombc
item.description:
@fellixombc wrote:

java or php.

join the java section, not the moparscaper one, moparscape teaches you nothing, only how to edit simple files.
Java can teach you how to make good programs or games.
Php though is a good scripting lang. Its good for fuctions like an auto responder, server status, log in system and many other things.

Of course you could always learn both

Read full topic

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Evil_, post:6, topic:171949”]Java seems to be an awesome starter language, seeing as it teaches you OOP, uses the syntax of C/++, so after learning some Java you can easily switch to C/++, D, or any other language whose syntax is derived from C++.

Java also protects the programmer from having to be very worried about things such as memory leaks. It also has easily understandable exception messages, which will help you debug your projects fairly easily.

Another thing, is Java is compatible on multiple operating systems, so instead of having to have it compiled on every system and worry about it not working, you can just release your project and know that all the user would have to do is download Java.[/quote]
<3 Evil_
Yeah, Java would be good first as it does teach you Object Orientated Programming.

Read full topic

item.title: Whats a good "first" programming language?
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

Java seems to be an awesome starter language, seeing as it teaches you OOP, uses the syntax of C/++, so after learning some Java you can easily switch to C/++, D, or any other language whose syntax is derived from C++.

Java also protects the programmer from having to be very worried about things such as memory leaks. It also has easily understandable exception messages, which will help you debug your projects fairly easily.

Another thing, is Java is compatible on multiple operating systems, so instead of having to have it compiled on every system and worry about it not working, you can just release your project and know that all the user would have to do is download Java.

EDIT:

Another good thing about Java is the fact that you can find basically all the documentation on 1 site, and there are many many tutorials everywhere on the internet to help you through learning.

Read full topic

item.description:

Java.
